repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Related and fixes #36986

Problem:
The `:checkhealth vim.treesitter` command shows available parsers but doesn't show which query files are available for each language. This makes it difficult for users to see what treesitter functionality (highlights, injections, folds, etc.) is available.

Solution:
Add a new 'Treesitter queries' section that lists all query files grouped by language, showing the path to each query file.

comment_data.body:
No, you cannot conclude that -- unlike parsers, multiple queries can be loaded at the same time (if one of them specifies `; extends` in their modeline).

You should list them all, but sort them -- per language -- in the order in which they appear on `runtimepath` (so you quickly see the "entrypoint", i.e., the query that is loaded _first_).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +64,53 @@ function M.check()
       )
     end
   end
+
+  health.start('Treesitter queries')
+  local query_files = vim.api.nvim_get_runtime_file('queries/**/*.scm', true)
+  ---@class QueryEntry
+  ---@field lang string
+  ---@field type string
+  ---@field path string
+  ---@field index integer
+  local queries_by_lang = {} ---@type table<string, QueryEntry[]>
+  for i, query_file in ipairs(query_files) do
+    local lang, query_type = query_file:match('queries/([^/]+)/([^/]+)%.scm$')
+    if lang and query_type then
+      if not queries_by_lang[lang] then
+        queries_by_lang[lang] = {}
+      end
+      table.insert(queries_by_lang[lang], {
+        lang = lang,
+        type = query_type,
+        path = query_file,
+        index = i,
+      })
+    end
+  end
+  if vim.tbl_isempty(queries_by_lang) then
+    health.warn('No query files found')
+  else
+    for lang, queries in vim.spairs(queries_by_lang) do
+      table.sort(queries, function(a, b)
+        if a.type == b.type then
+          return a.index < b.index
+        else
+          return a.type < b.type
+        end
+      end)
+
+      for i, query in ipairs(queries) do
+        local is_duplicate = i > 1 and queries[i - 1].type == query.type
+        if is_duplicate then
+          health.ok(
+            string.format('Language: %-15s %s (not loaded): %s', lang, query.type, query.path)

comment_data.body:
Thanks for the feedback! You're absolutely right about the difference between queries and parsers. I hadn't realized that multiple queries can be loaded via `; extends`, so marking some of them as **"(not loaded)"** does not make sense

I'll make the following changes:
1. **Remove the "(not loaded)" marker** - all the queries will be listed, since they can extend each other.
2. **Preserve runtime path ordering** - this keeps the entrypoint of queries clearly visible for each query type.

Regarding the validation and performance of parsing the queries for this functionality. I have few ideas and would love some feedback.
- Lazy loading and validating the queries
- Validating the queries only for the active buffers
- Maybe a way to on-demand validation per language, maybe like `vim.treesitter.lang` or parameters (only if possible)

Or should we keep the healthcheck simple without validation for now? Happy to implement whichever approach you think is best!

comment_data.body:
Not sure this should be a warning; there could be valid reasons for having a parser without any dedicated files.

(Conversely, you can have queries without a parser.)

comment_data.body: This list is going to be very unwieldy; I would recommend stripping the filename  (since it's redundant with the leading `type:`). You can use `vim.fn.fnamemodify` for that.

comment_data.body:
> yes i am, cause english is not my native and dont wanna have mistakes in them, which may mistakenly give wrong idea what i am talking

Please don't do that; LLM answers are soulless and waste everybody's time with repeated nonsense. As long as both sides are willing to put in a bit of effort and give the benefit of the doubt, the language should not be a barrier; I will try to explain more clearly. And if you feel the language is a barrier, it's perfectly fine to use a machine translation tool (Google Translate, DeepL, etc.) -- just write your comment in your native language and paste the translation (with a "translated" note at the end, if you want to be perfectly transparent).

> also I looked at nvim-treesitter and looked at how it check-queries and noticed it using vim.treesitter.query.get. Should i use that instead of looking and finding in the runtimepath instead?

No, that's a different check from just listing all available queries. Please keep your current approach; validating queries requires a bit more thought, and your first PR should be simple.

comment_data.body:
Thank you and I will make sure to not use LLM for answering here any more. Its not that language is barrier I can fully understand but just slowly.

and about validating queries, I will keep it simple right now but would love to learn how the queries are actually validated if you could maybe link me the files I should keep an eye on.

Ok from what I have gathered 
- I have to remove (Not loaded) marker and list all query files
- Preserve the runtimepath order
- remove the warning for not finding any query files
- remove the filename from path, as the type already shows what query is loaded

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        health.ok(string.format('%-15s %s: %s', lang, query.type, dir))
```
to use as much space as possible for the (potentially very long) paths. (If you label one column, you should label all columns; see the parser check.)

I think these columns are self-explanatory, but if not, we should add a heading. (The same goes for the parser check, but that is out of scope for this PR.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +64,48 @@ function M.check()
       )
     end
   end
+
+  health.start('Treesitter queries')
+  local query_files = vim.api.nvim_get_runtime_file('queries/**/*.scm', true)
+
+  ---@class QueryEntry
+  ---@field lang string
+  ---@field type string
+  ---@field path string
+  ---@field index integer
+  local queries_by_lang = {} ---@type table<string, QueryEntry[]>
+
+  for i, query_file in ipairs(query_files) do
+    local lang, query_type = query_file:match('queries/([^/]+)/([^/]+)%.scm$')
+    if lang and query_type then
+      if not queries_by_lang[lang] then
+        queries_by_lang[lang] = {}
+      end
+      table.insert(queries_by_lang[lang], {
+        lang = lang,
+        type = query_type,
+        path = query_file,
+        index = i,
+      })
+    end
+  end
+
+  if not vim.tbl_isempty(queries_by_lang) then
+    for lang, queries in vim.spairs(queries_by_lang) do
+      table.sort(queries, function(a, b)
+        if a.type == b.type then
+          return a.index < b.index
+        else
+          return a.type < b.type
+        end
+      end)
+
+      for _, query in ipairs(queries) do
+        local dir = vim.fn.fnamemodify(query.path, ':h')
+        health.ok(string.format('Language: %-15s %s: %s', lang, query.type, dir))

comment_regular_data.body:
Hey! Quick question about the CI checks:

**macOS Zig Build** - This one's failing and I'm not sure if it's something I need to fix? The error seems to be in the build system itself rather than my code, and the functional tests show 531/533 steps passed. Should I try anything on my end or is this a known CI issue?

**news.txt check** - The check is asking if I should update the documentation. I wasn't sure if this feature is significant enough to include in release notes. Happy to add an entry if you think users would benefit from knowing about it!

Thanks for reviewing! Let me know what I should do about these.

> macOS Zig Build

Yeah sometimes tests just fail. No clue why. You don't need to do anything.

> news.txt check

Yep, this can be skipped.

Note: Unlike the nvim-treesitter healthcheck, this doesn't check if the queries are valid (which is one of the biggest sources of issues). However, that requires actually parsing the queries, which can be quite slow.
A cosmetic suggestion for better readability: Can you align the query types in a separate column as you do the language names? (The longest name is probably going to be `textobjects`.)

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(treesitter): show query files in healthcheck
